name: Physical object
feedback: Represents something with tangible physical presence.

name: Man-made / synthetic
feedback: Created or manufactured by humans rather than occurring naturally.

name: Biological or biologically-inspired
feedback: Derived from or modeled after biological systems or organisms.

name: Fixed/static
feedback: Maintains a consistent, unchanging form or position.

name: Structural
feedback: Serves primarily as a supportive or load-bearing component.

name: Perceptible
feedback: Can be detected or sensed directly by human perception.

name: Material form
feedback: Exists as matter rather than being purely conceptual.

name: Passive
feedback: Does not actively initiate changes or outputs on its own.

name: Purposeful / intentional
feedback: Designed with a specific function or goal in mind.

name: Emits output / produces effect
feedback: Generates a change, output, or impact on its environment.

name: Processes or regulates logic/signals
feedback: Handles, controls, or transforms information or signals.

name: Transforms or modifies internal state
feedback: Undergoes internal changes in condition, status, or form.

name: Interacts with humans directly
feedback: Designed for direct engagement, use, or response by humans.

name: Part of a larger system
feedback: Functions as a component within a broader interconnected system.

name: Autonomous in function
feedback: Operates independently without needing continuous external control.

name: System-critical
feedback: Essential to the operation or success of a larger system.

name: Symbolic / representational
feedback: Stands for or represents something beyond itself.

name: Communicative
feedback: Conveys information, ideas, or meaning to others.

name: Logical / rule-based
feedback: Organized according to a set of rules, principles, or formal structures.

name: Hierarchical / modular
feedback: Organized in layers, levels, or modular subunits.

name: Behavior-guiding
feedback: Influences or prescribes behavior, decisions, or actions.

name: Self-referential / meta-conceptual
feedback: Refers to or describes itself or its own category.

name: Temporal
feedback: Relates to time, timing, or sequences of change.

name: Contextual abstraction
feedback: Derives meaning from the surrounding context rather than being absolute.

name: Socially / culturally constructed
feedback: Defined primarily by collective human agreements, traditions, or culture.

name: Defined by a group/system
feedback: Recognized or sustained by the agreement of a broader group or system.

name: Linked to identity or role
feedback: Associated with social identity, status, or function.

name: Regulated / governed
feedback: Subject to rules, laws, standards, or enforcement.

name: Teachable / transmissible
feedback: Knowledge about it can be formally taught or passed on to others.

name: Visible
feedback: Its existence or attributes are outwardly observable.

name: Context-sensitive
feedback: Meaning or behavior changes based on surrounding circumstances.

name: Widely known
feedback: Recognized and understood by a broad public audience.
